conclusion: To determine when the two objects meet, we need to analyze their motion based on the velocity-time graph provided.
The key idea is that the two objects meet when they have traveled the same distance from their starting point.
The distance traveled by an object is the area under its velocity-time graph.
The graph shows the velocity (v) of Object A and Object B as a function of time (t).
Object A starts with an initial velocity (v0) and its velocity decreases over time, reaching zero at t2.
Object B starts from rest (v = 0) at t1, and its velocity increases, reaching v0 at t4.
The distance traveled by an object is the area under its velocity-time curve.
For Object A, the area under its curve from t = 0 to any time t gives the distance it has traveled.
For Object B, the area under its curve from t = t1 to any time t gives the distance it has traveled.
The two objects meet when the total area under the velocity-time curve of Object A equals the total area under the velocity-time curve of Object B.
From t = 0 to t2, Object A is moving while Object B is stationary.
During the time from t = 0 to t2, Object A accumulates a distance equal to the triangular area under its curve.
From t1 onward, Object B starts moving, and its distance is represented by the area under its curve.
The two objects meet when the total area under Object A's curve equals the total area under Object B's curve.
The red lines in the second image show the areas under the curves for both objects.
At t = t3, the total area under Object A's curve (from t = 0 to t3) equals the total area under Object B's curve (from t = t1 to t3).
The two objects meet at t = t3.
